intro: Abutilon × hybridum, commonly known as the Chinese lantern plant, is a species native to Southeast Asia. It is a deciduous shrub or small tree that can grow up to 3 meters tall. The plant is characterized by its velvety, heart-shaped leaves and vibrant orange to red bracts that resemble lanterns. It produces small, yellow flowers that are followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. The plant thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soil.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon × hybridum is primarily native to tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas, including parts of Central and South America. It is commonly found in countries such as Brazil, Mexico, and Peru. This plant thrives in warm, humid climates and is often associated with disturbed or open habitats. It is also known to grow in coastal areas and along riverbanks. Its natural range extends into the Caribbean as well.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon × hybridum was mainly introduced to New Zealand North and New Zealand South. It is a hybrid species that likely resulted from the cross between Abutilon theophrasti and Abutilon indicum. This plant has been established in these regions, possibly due to its ornamental value or accidental introduction through human activity. It is considered an invasive species in some areas, outcompeting native flora. Its distribution in New Zealand highlights the ecological impact of introduced plant species.
